But the coffee and milk mixing process, even when viewed during the interesting middle of the process, does create any entities that reproduce themselves or self-perpetuate in an ongoing process with stable or increasing complexity. Part of the reason that does not occur is that the coffee/milk mixing process as discussed here is just a single batch, while living ecosystems on Earth depend on a continuous (on a global scale) influx of light energy.

To my knowledge, the best we can say about an entropy-increasing region is that, once a continuous pipeline process is established and becomes (globally) steady-state, self-reproducing processes might come into existence. Those that do appear will by their very nature persist as patterns that repeat indefinitely.
Providing more useful energy does not enter our alleged closed system. And it all might be an illusion since entropy relies on the arrow of time.

They seem to frame this as an explanation of the spontaneous generation of life (0:15) but they only talk about Entropy and Complexity. IMHO Complexity is almost meaningless as it is only a measure of how "long" it takes to describe a state and says nothing about its meaning; a more accurate marker for the origin of life would be Information. Our DNA contains a vast amount of information (and also complexity). The important difference is that a random DNA mutation would likely increase complexity but would almost certainly not increase information. I personally am having trouble coming up with a scenario where information is spontaneously generated (its the whole "million monkeys on typewriters trying to write shakespeare" argument but with even worse odds). I'm not saying evolution and the spontaneous generation of life didn't happen or isn't possible, I'm saying that the odds are so astronomically unlikely (even with all the time in the universe) that other, seemly absurd, options almost seem more plausible. Remember, God hasn't been proven by science, but neither has He been disproven.

Je pense que la "complexité" dans l'univers ne vas pas diminuer, je pense même qu'elle va croître. Étant donné que nos activités en tant "qu'entité complexe" permette d'accélérer le désordre de l'univers [S(cellule)+S(environnement)] > (ou) = 0], je pense que l'univers aura plus tendance à "perpétré" des "entité complexe" (d'abord de manière aléatoire puis de manière à sélectionné le "catalyseur à désordre" le plus efficace). Ce qui se passe sans la "complexité" c'est que la chose la plus ordonné dans l'univers (la matière) va au fur est à mesur se transformer en énergie (qui est moins ordonné) et va se dissoudre dans l'univers très lentement. Ce processus prend beaucoup de temps de manière naturelle, à cause de la stabilité de la matière et de sa quantité énorme d'énergie qu'elle renferme. L'univers à donc trouver la vie comme moyen d'augmenter l'entropie.
Ce que je pense aussi c'est qu'au début de l'univers l'espace était plus petits que la quantité d'énergie et que comme une réaction chimique réversible, l'énergie c'est converti en matière par manque de place. (maintenant c'est l'inverse qui se produit.)
Et puis l'univers c'est étendu de manière exponentielle et à créée plus d'espace avant que la matière n'ai le temps de se retransformer en énergie (l'espérance de vie de la matière est des million de millions de millénaire!). Les interactions entre matière, appuyer par la force qui pousse le désordre (l'exception de l'univers) va sélection des processus de plus en plus complexe! I tend to like MinutePhysics videos. But this one bothers me quite a bit. The problem is that the concept of "complexity" that you use in this video is very ill-defined and vague for this video being made by a scientist. The way you use the term "complexity" is what is usually referred to as "information content" (what is the amount of information you have to provide to completely describe a system), which is nor usually referred to as "complexity".... Also, the part where you describe "entropy" as the number of combinations is plain wrong. For example, the number of possible states of a system with a fixed number of particles does not increase over time, while its entropy can increase. Entropy is defined over the probability distribution of the states or properties of the system. The more skewed the distribution (i.e., the more order), the less entropy. Maximum entropy is achieved when you have an even distribution (i.e., a system where all states are equiprobable, which basically means that the degree of randomness is maximum). This video confuses more than clarifies things... sorry for being critical though, I usually really like all your videos.
